utterance.content: Well, I thought you might want to know how Cynthia died. She was drowned, in motor oil.

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: Motor oil?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It's almost as if whoever did it had a personal connection to the bombing.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Adam, if I looked in your garage right now, would I find motor oil?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: I own a boat and a car, Detective.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And where were you last Tuesday?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: I bartend at the Foxtail Grill on Manchester every Tuesday. Are we done?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes. For now. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You know what? I hope his alibi checks out. I hope he didn't do it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And here I thought you would be saying what a great story it would make if Adam Pike did it. A son taking revenge for his father.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It is a good story. It's a great story. Personally, I would just write a happier ending for that family.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Beckett. FBI files on the tanker bombing in '89. I've been going through them.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Three days after the bombing, they captured Jared Swanstrom at a motel where he'd been hiding out. Feds had a tip line. Some helpful citizen calls, and said they'd seen Swanstrom at the motel. Feds go in, grab him up. Easy-peasy.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It's pretty standard stuff.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yeah, until you get to the part where the tipster never collects on the reward.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And who was the tipster?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: That's just it. The FBI never knew because she didn't leave a name.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: "She"?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. Records describe the voice as "young and female."

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It could be Cynthia Dern. Do you think she would give up her friends to the cops?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Doesn't matter what I think. Only matters what Swanstrom thought. The guy did fifteen years in prison.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That's a long time to think about who put you there.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Jared Swanstrom?

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: NYPD. We'd like to ask you some questions about Cynthia Dern.

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: I'm not sure what I can tell you. I hadn't seen her in twenty years.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But you knew she was writing a book, right? You spoke to Lee Wax.

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: Yeah, I spoke with her. I-- I told her to give Cynthia my regards.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, you weren't bearing any old grudges?

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: Against Cynthia? What for?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: For turning you in. It was Cynthia one who called the cops the night you were arrested.

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: Well, if that's true, she was just trying to save herself. Right after the bombing, Cynthia wanted to run, try to make it to Canada, but I, uh, I fell apart.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: Guilt. I'm the one who built the bomb. I'm the one who messed it up.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: "Messed it up" how?

utterance.speaker: SWANSTROM
utterance.content: The girls were supposed to have three minutes to get off that ship before it went off. Three minutes. But when Cynthia got back in the car that night, she said that something had gone wrong; that the bomb had... had blown early. I'm the reason that Susan Mailer is dead.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: At least one of them took responsibility for what happened that night.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. Maybe even a little too much responsibility.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: You don't believe Jared Swanstrom's story?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That's the thing. It's not his story, it's Cynthia's.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: You want to break it down for those of us who've already had a glass of wine?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Cynthia told Lee Wax that she and Susan Mailer had an argument as to whether or not to set off the bomb, once they knew the captain was on board. Cynthia backed out. Susan went on to set off the bomb by herself. And... "Boom."

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Huh.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: But today, Jared Swanstrom said that Cynthia told him there was something wrong with the timer. She never said anything about an argument.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh. Well, that is a rather glaring omission.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You know, when I'm writing, I find it's all about choices. What to put in. What to leave out. When to reveal some information, when to hold something back... But as someone else's ghostwriter, you only know what they want you to know.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: But Lee Wax isn't Cynthia's ghostwriter anymore, right? Now that she's dead, it's no longer a memoir. It's a true crime story. And it sounds like the true story is a whole lot juicier than Cynthia's lies.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Good morning.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh! Hey. Sorry. I've just...

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: ...been going over Lee Wax's interview notes. When she spoke to Jared Swanstrom, he told her the same thing he told us: Cynthia said the bomb blew early. But she left that version out of her book.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That's because it contradicted Cynthia's latest story: that the girls argued when they discovered that Captain Pike was still on board, and that Susan set the bomb alone.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: According to the publisher, Cynthia has full approval over everything Lee Wax wrote. It was her way or the highway.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You talked to the publisher?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I am somewhat known in those circles. Anyway, they didn't like it. They were looking for a true crime tell-all, and what they were getting was some sanitized bunch of remorseful boohooing. They were getting ready to pull the plug.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And now?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, now that Cynthia's murder's all over the media, they're back on board, so long as the book takes a more sensationalized angle. Kaboom! "The True Story of a Domestic Terrorist Turned Suburban Housewife and the Crime that Shocked America".

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Catchy.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So with Cynthia out of the way, Lee Wax is sitting on a potential best-seller.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: People have killed for a lot less.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Beckett. All right, bring him in.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Adam Pike's alibi fell apart. He was lying about being at work on Tuesday night.

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: I didn't kill her. I didn't even know where she was.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We're not gonna get anywhere if you keep lying to me. I know you went to Westchester. I spoke to Cynthia's husband. He remembers seeing a guy just like you outside their house a couple weeks before she was murdered. Don't make me put you in a lineup.

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: I just... wanted to talk to her.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: How'd you find her?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: That writer. The way she kept talking about what happened to my dad, she knew things that only someone on that ship could know. So, I started following her around. Eventually, she led me to Cynthia Dern.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And why didn't you call the police?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: Because I wanted to look her in the eye. I wanted to tell her none of it mattered. Her blood money wouldn't buy our forgiveness.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What money?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What do you mean by "blood money"?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: After I found out where Cynthia lived, I went and told my mom. I didn't know if we should call the Feds or what. She started crying. She told me we'd been getting money every month since the bombing. Different amounts. Sometimes more, sometimes less. But every month.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And she thought that the money was coming from Cynthia Dern?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: The first envelope there was a note, "Please forgive me." Susan Mailer was dead. Swanstrom was in prison. There wasn't anybody else.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You know, with this kind of evidence, Cynthia would have been caught years ago.

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: Mom said without that money, we wouldn't have made it. She figured as long as Cynthia was free, the money would keep coming.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, why did you lie to me about where you were last Tuesday?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: Because I was there. At the hotel. I followed her. I was just going to talk to her. I spent an hour walking up and down that hallway, trying to get up the courage to go and knock on that door, you know? I was gonna do it. But then someone got off the elevator and knocked on her door instead.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You saw her killer?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: I didn't get a good look, but I did heard them talking, and I can tell you one thing.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: It was a woman.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Lee Wax.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Beckett! It was Lee Wax! Beckett! Lee Wax. Lee...

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Murder? Are you people crazy?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I have an eyewitness who can place you at the SRO where Cynthia's body was found.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You had motive, means, and opportunity.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Please. Only a novelist could come up with a twist this absurd.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not as absurd as killing a woman to salvage your story. Drowning her in motor oil gave you just the ending you needed.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: I'm a true crime writer, so I don't have your talent for fiction.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We know your publisher wanted to dump your contract.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Because I told them that I thought Cynthia was lying.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, you didn't believe her remorse was genuine?

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: When Cynthia cried, it was for herself. She wanted to cash in and keep herself out of jail, that's it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, she must have felt some responsibility for what happened. After all, she sent the Pikes money year after year.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: What money?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Every month since the bombing, the Pikes have been receiving money, courtesy of Cynthia Dern. Only, there's nothing about that in your notes.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Because she never told me. Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We're sure.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Look, the Tuesday that Cynthia was killed, I was out to dinner with my publisher until after midnight. So, I couldn't have killed her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Remind me if I ever decide to write a memoir, to never write a memoir.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Because memoirs are about the truth, and I'm not a very truthful person. It'd be too easy to make myself look good.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Might be harder than you think.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe. But I would sure start with the most generous thing I ever did.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You mean, like how you anonymously sent money to your victims, because you felt so guilty about what you'd done?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The object of Cynthia's memoir was to gain sympathy. What could be more sympathetic than sending the Pikes guilt money for twenty years?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It doesn't make sense that Cynthia didn't tell Lee Wax.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Unless the money didn't come from Cynthia.

utterance.speaker: CAPTAIN MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: It had to be from Cynthia. Swanstrom was in prison and Susan Mailer was dead.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, just the three of them. Assuming you believe the FBI.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You know, we don't really have to talk about this.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Anything to stop His Honor here from talking about budget initiatives.

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Oh, okay, Judge. Who was it that appointed you again?

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Now, the FBI I believe. But why take Cynthia Dern's word for anything that happened the night of the bombing, when her own ghostwriter didn't even trust her?

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: You know, the judge is right. What do we actually know about what happened?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Not much. According to Lee Wax's notes, Captain Pike heard two women arguing just before the explosion. Cynthia claims that she was trying to change Susan's mind.

utterance.speaker: CAPTAIN MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Fold. But if we assume Cynthia was lying...

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Then maybe it was Susan that wanted to save Pike, and Cynthia that wanted to run. Raise twenty.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Right! But the bomb was already set, so the three-minute timer is already ticking.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: The girls argue, wasting precious seconds--

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Susan runs towards the ticking bomb to try to shut it down--

utterance.speaker: CAPTAIN MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: While Cynthia runs for cover.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Right. Susan gets to the bomb, but too late.

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Boom.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Which means Susan Mailer didn't die trying to set the bomb.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: She died trying to save an innocent man's life. Fold.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It still doesn't explain where the money came from.

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Fold. Well, what about it, Castle? You're good with twists. Where'd the money come from?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I'm thinking.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, well, you might want to think up some chips for the pot, 'cause it looks like it's just you and me.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: All right, Detective Beckett. I'm all in. Oh, what's the matter? You afraid of a little action?

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Oh, do us a favor, Detective. Beat his pants off.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, please. Beat my pants off, if you dare.

utterance.speaker: CAPTAIN MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Beckett, do me proud.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: To hell with "proud." Make him cry like a little girl.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sorry, fellas. It's just not my night.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Who's a good little boy? Who's a good little boy? You are. And you are. And you are.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Don't you ever get tired of winning, Castle?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah, you'd think so, right? But no.

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Well, I think that's it for me. Detective, it was a pleasure.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Mayor.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Sorry we couldn't solve your case.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And I'm sorry I couldn't make him cry like a little girl.

utterance.speaker: MAYOR
utterance.content: Well, it's not your fault, Detective. No matter how down he gets, he always manages to rise from the dead.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, now that'd be a twist.

utterance.speaker: CAPTAIN MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The money had to come from Cynthia because Swanstrom was in jail and Susan Mailer was dead, right?

utterance.speaker: JUDGE MARKWAY
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But what if Susan Mailer didn't die in that explosion? What if she's still alive?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Susan Mailer? Alive?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Her body was never found.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah. Because she was vaporized in the explosion.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, maybe she was thrown clear.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Well, then, she would've been badly burned and would've needed care.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: And no one matching her description ever checked into area hospitals.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Mere details, my good man.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Um, around here, we call them "facts."

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well then, let's go get us some "facts."

utterance.speaker: ELEANOR
utterance.content: Please don't think less of me. I did what I had to do to survive.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: These are from all over the place.

utterance.speaker: ADAM
utterance.content: Not the recent ones. The recent ones are all the same.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Lititz, Pennsylvania.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: If we're gonna road-trip, I'm gonna have to pee first.

utterance.speaker: POST OFFICE CLERK
utterance.content: I've never seen her before.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you positive?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Didn't he sound positive?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Castle.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, how about her?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She'd be older now.

utterance.speaker: POST OFFICE CLERK
utterance.content: How much older?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Twenty years.

utterance.speaker: POST OFFICE CLERK
utterance.content: I don't think so.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That's what I get for listening to a mystery writer.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: She might have scars or walk with a limp.

utterance.speaker: POST OFFICE CLERK
utterance.content: Like she's been in an accident? It could be Mary Wright.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mary Wright?

utterance.speaker: POST OFFICE CLERK
utterance.content: She comes in once a month or so, buys a money order to send to her relatives in New York.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you have her address?

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: It sounds naïve now, but, um... everything I did back then, I did because I thought it would help.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We're not here because of the bombing, Susan. We're here because of what you did to Cynthia Dern.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Her body was found in a tub of motor oil. But you already know that.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Forensics is going through that room as we speak. And believe me, they will find something. Something that connects you to Cynthia's death.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: She should have just left it all alone. She had a husband, a good life. Well, that wasn't Cynthia. Once she decided on something, well, you just better not be in her way.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Like that night on the tanker.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: I saw the captain go below. I don't know how he got back on board without us seeing...I-- I tried... I was, I was too late. When the bomb exploded, I was thrown overboard. I can still feel the heat on my skin... even today.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: How did you survive without medical attention?

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: Um, a friend took me in, a med student. Nursed me back to health. I got a new identity.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And Mary Wright was born.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: It isn't hard to live like a ghost when everyone you love thinks you're dead. I never contacted anyone from my former life, not even my parents.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But you still sent money to the Pikes.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: They had a son, medical bills. I-- I was responsible. Everything could have stayed just the way it was, except...

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Except Cynthia decided to write a book.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: That reporter put a post on an environmental board asking for info on Cynthia. I e-mailed, pretending to be an old friend of "the group." It didn't take long for me to figure out that she had found Cynthia, and Cynthia was lying about what happened on the ship.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You tracked her down. You confronted her.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: I threatened to turn myself in if she went through with the book. Give myself up, tell the authorities everything. She begged to meet with me first. Somewhere we could talk.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That's when you rented the room?

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: Oh, no. Cynthia rented the room, not me. It was all part of her plan.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Her plan?

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: Her plan to murder me. When I got there, she poured me a drink. "Let's toast to old friends," she said. Only, you see, I don't drink. I tried to leave. She wouldn't let me. I hid in the bathroom. That's when I saw it. A tub full of oil. Then, I understood.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: She didn't plan to talk to you. She planned to kill you and make it look like suicide. That wine was laced with a sleeping pill. You were supposed to drink it, and then drown in the oil.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And then the world would think that you were wracked with guilt over the Pikes all these years, and that you finally decided to commit suicide.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Once your body was discovered, the public would clamor for the "true" story. Cynthia's true story, with you now cast as the villain.

utterance.speaker: SUSAN
utterance.content: We struggled. She lost her balance and fell against the sink and hit her head. I should've called for help. But I just wanted it to be over. So I... I dragged her to the tub, and... I... I pushed her in. You see, I was already dead. I just wanted to keep it that way.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: I heard you made an arrest.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You can hear all about it in the morning news.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: Oh, come on. After all the help I gave you on this case, you can't give me any more information than that?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, I could. But I just keep thinking that, if it wasn't for you, there wouldn't be a case in the first place.

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: All the people from Cynthia's past that you interviewed... How did you manage to let every one of them know you were in contact with her?

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: What are you implying?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You wanted someone to put two-and-two together and call the cops. You wanted Cynthia in prison. That way, you could tear up the contract you had with her and write the story you wanted to write. With an ending that would sell more books. I mean, you couldn't call the authorities yourself. What kind of story would that be?

utterance.speaker: LEE
utterance.content: That's a lovely theory. But even if it's true, I didn't kill Cynthia. I didn't even do anything illegal.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, no, no, no. It's not illegal, it's just slimy. So your, uh, all-access pass has been revoked.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, and one more thing. One day, and one day not far from now, I'm gonna use this in a book.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
